title: good will vs goodwill | WordReference Forums
text: perpend Banned American English Doing nothing risks going over the cliff even as his repeated attempts to bludgeon Republicans on taxes while offering no new concessions has engendered little good will toward the president. Chicago Tribune, 12/6/12. I can't find it online, so I can't provide a link. This is a bear of a sentence, in some ways, but wouldn't a proofreader or editor have chosen to write "good will" as one word ("goodwill") here, for clarity? This is hilarious, but the LA Times has it as one word: Obama's strategy involves risks. His repeated attempts to bludgeon Republicans on taxes while offering no new concessions has engendered little goodwill, and he will need some Republican votes soon. http://articles.latimes.com/2012/dec/05/nation/la-na-fiscal-cliff-20121206 Ironic, since the Tribune owns the Times, as far as I know. Midwest/West Coast style? Chicago Tribune, 12/6/12. I can't find it online, so I can't provide a link. Midwest/West Coast style?
